key_title: Key to the genera of Santalaceae

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons

source.author: Jeanes, J.A.; Lepschi, B.J.
source.title: Santalaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Jeanes, J.A.; Lepschi, B.J. (1999). Santalaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Plants rooted in the ground (but parasitic, albeit not obviously, on roots of other species); throughout Victoria
Plant leafy, often golden-yellow, stems neither conspicuosly flattened or jointed; usually growing on other mistletoes; often on Dendrophthoe vitellina in Victoria
Plant with minute scale-like leaves at nodes of flattened jointed stems, but appearing leafless, dark green; usually growing on Syzygium smithii in Victoria.
Weak, erect herb or subshrub to c. 40 cm high; peduncle united to base of sub- tending leaf; inflorescence 1-flowered
Woody shrubs or trees, rarely prostrate; peduncle, when present, free from base of subtending leaf; inflorescence a raceme, spike, panicle, corymb or cluster, occasionally reduced to a single flower
Ovary superior; receptacle often enlarged and fleshy below drupe
Ovary inferior; receptacle not enlarged and fleshy below drupe
Plant dioecious; branches resinous and lustrous; leaves absent; eastern and north- eastern Victoria only
Plant with bisexual flowers; branches neither resinous nor lustrous; leaves present at least on young branches, though often small and caducous
Leaves well-developed, opposite or whorled, persistent
Leaves small or scale-like, alternate, often caducous
Flowers single or in clusters, each flower subtended by 2 or more persistent bracteoles; drupe scarcely succulent
Flowers in lateral spikes or racemes, each flower subtended by a single deciduous bract; drupe succulent
